article_title: GOP targets Begich over Affordable Care Act
article_text: Of the 9,000 or so individuals covered in Alaska by Premera, just under 5,400 were faced with losing their insurance before the reprieve, said Premera spokesman Eric Earling. Premera reenrolled them, though they could opt out by Dec. 31. Most likely will stick with their old plans, which generally should be less expensive than what's offered on the federally-run insurance marketplace unless the individual qualifies for a subsidy, Earling said. Some objected to requirements that new plans offer pediatric dental care and maternity care, even for a single man with no children, he said.

article_metadata.description: A fresh round in an expected torrent of campaign ads targeting Sen. Mark Begich over flaws in the Affordable Care Act is hitting Alaska this week. But the new round of ads isn't what the Republicans talked it up to be.

og.description: A fresh round in an expected torrent of campaign ads targeting Sen. Mark Begich over flaws in the Affordable Care Act is hitting Alaska this week. But the new round of ads isn't what the Republicans talked it up to be.
og.title: GOP targets Begich over Affordable Care Act - with ad that airs just once

article_summary:
Some objected to requirements that new plans offer pediatric dental care and maternity care, even for a single man with no children, he said.
Of the 9,000 or so individuals covered in Alaska by Premera, just under 5,400 were faced with losing their insurance before the reprieve, said Premera spokesman Eric Earling.
Most likely will stick with their old plans, which generally should be less expensive than what's offered on the federally-run insurance marketplace unless the individual qualifies for a subsidy, Earling said.
Premera reenrolled them, though they could opt out by Dec. 31.
